_GeneralInformation.Description: This dataset is a collection of component-level damage models from the literature and public resources. Every entry has one or more corresponding publications identified that provide more information about its calibration and application limits.

References.canfield1991: Canfield, L. R., Niu, S. H., & Liu, H. (1991). Uplift resistance of various rafter-wall connections. Forest products journal, 41(7-8), 27-34.
References.cheng2004: Cheng, J. (2004). Testing and analysis of the toe-nailed connection in the residential roof-to-wall system. Forest products journal, 54(4).
References.dong2016: Dong, Y., & Li, Y. (2016). Risk-based assessment of wood residential construction subjected to hurricane events considering indirect and environmental loss. Sustainable and Resilient Infrastructure, 1(1-2), 46-62.
References.gurley2005: Gurley, K., Pinelli, J.-P., Subramanian, C., Cope, A., Zhang, L., Murphree, J., Artiles, A., Misra, P., Gulati, S., and Simiu, E. (2005). Florida Public Hurricane Loss Projection Model engineering team final report volume II: Predicting the vulnerability of typical residential buildings to hurricane damage. Technical report, International Hurricane Research Center, Florida International University
References.jain2020: Jain, A., Bhusar, A. A., Roueche, D. B., & Prevatt, D. O. (2020). Engineering-based tornado damage assessment: numerical tool for assessing tornado vulnerability of residential structures. Frontiers in Built Environment, 6, 89.
References.li2006: Li, Y., & Ellingwood, B. R. (2006). Hurricane damage to residential construction in the US: Importance of uncertainty modeling in risk assessment. Engineering structures, 28(7), 1009-1018. Li, Y., van de Lindt, J. W., Dao, T., Bjarnadottir, S., & Ahuja, A. (2012). Loss analysis for combined wind and surge in hurricanes. Natural hazards review, 13(1), 1-10.
References.peng2013: Peng, Jiazhen. Modeling natural disaster risk management: Integrating the roles of insurance and retrofit and multiple stakeholder perspectives. University of Delaware, 2013.
References.reed1996: Reed, T. D., Rosowsky, D. V., & Schiff, S. D. (1996). Roof rafter to top-plate connections in coastal residential construction. In International Wood Engineering Conference (pp. 4-458).
References.reed1997: Reed, T. D., Rosowsky, D. V., & Schiff, S. D. (1997). Uplift capacity of light-frame rafter to top plate connections. Journal of architectural engineering, 3(4), 156-163.
References.shanmugam2009: Shanmugam, B., Nielson, B. G., & Prevatt, D. O. (2009). Statistical and analytical models for roof components in existing light-framed wood structures. Engineering Structures, 31(11), 2607-2616.
References.vandelindt2013: van de Lindt, J. W., Pei, S., Dao, T., Graettinger, A., Prevatt, D. O., Gupta, R., & Coulbourne, W. (2013). Dual-objective-based tornado design philosophy. Journal of Structural Engineering, 139(2), 251-263.
References.vickery2006: Vickery, P. J., Skerlj, P. F., Lin, J., Twisdale Jr, L. A., Young, M. A., & Lavelle, F. M. (2006). HAZUS-MH hurricane model methodology. II: Damage and loss estimation. Natural Hazards Review, 7(2), 94-103.

RWC.TN.STR.001.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and a small strap inside
RWC.TN.STR.001.Comments: The small strap is located on the inside of the wall.

RWC.TN.STR.002.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and a small strap outside
RWC.TN.STR.002.Comments: The small strap is located on the outside of the wall.

RWC.TN.STR.003.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and small straps on both sides
RWC.TN.STR.003.Comments: Two small straps are installed, one inside and one outside of the wall.

RWC.TN.STR.004.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, a small strap outside, and plywood nailed.
RWC.TN.STR.004.Comments: The small strap is located on the outside of the wall. A plywood is nailed to the plate on the wall as spacer.

RWC.TN.STR.005.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, a small strap outside, and plywood not nailed.
RWC.TN.STR.005.Comments: The small strap is located on the outside of the wall. A plywood is installed as spacer but not nailed to the plate on the wall.

RWC.TN.STR.006.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and a large strap outside
RWC.TN.STR.006.Comments: The large strap is located on the outside of the wall.

RWC.TN.STR.007.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and a large strap inside
RWC.TN.STR.007.Comments: The large strap is located on the inside of the wall.

RWC.EPX.001.Comments: Epoxy set for one week, no toe nails used.

RWC.TN.EPX.001.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and epoxy.
RWC.TN.EPX.001.Comments: Epoxy set for one week, toe-nailed when epoxy is wet.

RWC.TN.EPX.002.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and epoxy on small wood blocks.

RWC.TN.EPX.003.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and epoxy on small wood blocks.

RWC.TN.EPX.004.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and epoxy on large wood blocks.

RWC.TN.ADH.001.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and acrylic adhesive
RWC.TN.ADH.001.Comments: Adhesive set for one week, toe-nailed when adhesive is wet.

RWC.TN.ADH.002.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and soaked with acrylic adhesive.
RWC.TN.ADH.002.Comments: Wood first soaked for 24 hours, then toe-nailed when adhesive is wet.

RWC.TN.ADH.003.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and acrylic adhesive on small wood blocks.

RWC.TN.ADH.004.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and 1/4 inch acrylic adhesive bead

RWC.TN.ADH.005.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and 1/2 inch acrylic adhesive bead

RWC.TN.ADH.006.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and foaming polyurethane adhesive.

RWC.TN.002.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails and Simpson Strong-Tie H10.
RWC.TN.002.Comments: Simpson Strong-Tie H10 metal connector installed on every truss.

RWC.HCL.001a.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Hurricane Clip H2.5.

RWC.HCL.001b.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Hurricane Clip H2.5.

RWC.HCL.001c.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Hurricane Clip H2.5.

RWC.TN.003a.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 2-16d layout.

RWC.TN.003b.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 2-16d layout.

RWC.TN.004.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 3-8d layout.

RWC.TN.005.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 3-16d layout.

RWC.TN.006a.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 2-16d layout, box nails.

RWC.TN.006b.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 2-16d layout, box nails.

RWC.TN.006c.Description: Roof-Wall Connection with Toe nails, 2-16d layout, box nails.
